title: Protocol for construction and characterization of direct electron transfer-based enzyme-electrode using gold binding peptide as molecular binder
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Starter culture
Timing: 24 h
This section describes transforming the the expression hosts and prepare start cultures.
Transform expression plasmid into Escherichia coli BL21-Rosetta (DE3) with heat shock method.
Plate on LB agar plates containing 100 μg/mL of ampicillin and incubate 14–16 h Tat 37°C.
Pick a single colony from LB-ampicillin agar plate that has been incubated 14–16 h and inoculate a starter culture of 5 mL LB-ampicillin medium and incubate at 37°C for 8 h.
Inoculate Terrific Broth (TB) medium containing 100 μg/mL ampicillin with the starter culture at a 1:50 dilution.
Enzyme expression and purification
Timing: 30 h
This section describes the cultivation of expression hosts and performing the extraction and purification of target proteins.
Culture the Escherichia coli BL21-Rosetta (DE3) harboring target gene containing plasmid in 500 mL TB medium containing 100 μg/mL ampicillin in 1 L flask at 37°C. Let the cells grow for 2–3 h until OD600 reaches to 0.6.
Add IPTG to a final concentration of 0.2 mM and further incubate the cell culture at 16°C for 18 h.
Harvest the cells by centrifugation at 3,500 g and 4°C for 20 min.
Mix harvested cells with adding 15 mL Buffer A50 (pH 7.4).
Disrupt the resuspended cells by sonication (VCX 500, Sonics & Materials) using 150 cycles of 2 s ON and 4 s OFF at 40% amplitude (500 Watts and 20 kHz frequency) to assure complete cell lysis.
Centrifuge the lysates at 13,000 g and 4°C for 30 min.
Collect the supernatant and filter it through 0.45-μm syringe filter (ADVANTEC) to remove remaining cell debris and inclusion bodies.
Note: This step is essential to increase protein purity.
Equilibrate the filtered soluble fractions (∼15 mL) with Ni-NTA agarose resin (4 mL) with end-to-end rotation (40 rpm).

The nickel affinity agarose resin is priorly equilibrated with Buffer A50 (pH 7.4).
Wash the column with Buffer A50 (pH 7.4) of 10 column volumes.
Pass the two column volumes of Buffer A70, Buffer A350, and Buffer A500 (pH 7.4) through nickel column, sequentially.
Exchange the protein-containing buffer with PBS (pH 7.4) using a Amicon Ultra-15 30K filter (Millipore) centrifugal filter.
Select a molecular weight cut-off (MWCO) close to one-third the molecular weight of the target protein size.
Remove the his-tag by cleaving the TEV protease recognition site with the treatment of TEV protease. (NEB).
Estimate the protein concentration by Bradford assay (Bradford, 1976[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]).
Adjust the protein concentration to be 0.33 μg/μL in 45 μL total volume.
Add 5 μL of TEV Protease Reaction Buffer (10×) (NEB).
Add 1 μL of TEV Protease (10 U) (NEB).
Incubate at 30°C for 2 h.
Conform the cleavage of his-tag on 10% SDS-PAGE gel.
To remove or minimize cleaved his-tag and TEV protease (∼28 kDa) contents, filter the protein mixture through Amicon Ultra-15 30K filter (Millipore).
Note: The retention of protein structure after cleavage of his-tag could be confirmed with comparison of catalytic activities of protein before/after TEV protease treatment.
Note: The obtained proteins is recommended to be stored at 4°C and utilized within a week to avoid possible protein structural change which can lead to variation in biochemical and electrochemical results.
Note: The obtained protein concentration could be largely varied depending on protein types.
Enzyme activity assay
Timing: 20 min
This section describes the measurements of the enzyme activity for glucose oxidation by DCIP assay.
Prepare 60 μL DCIP mixture in 96-well plate (SPL) at 25°C as indicated in materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment] section (Inose et al., 2003[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]).

Add 20 μL purified enzyme (0.05 mg/mL) and incubate at 25°C for 3 min without stirring.
Add 20 μL of 2 M glucose to initiate glucose oxidation, or 20 μL of deionized water to perform blank at OD600.
After 1 min, stop the reaction by adding 100 μL of 6 M Urea and measure adsorption at OD600.
Calculate enzyme activity based on the Beer-Lambert Law (Swinehart, 1962[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]).
Note: Enzyme activity (U) = (Aglucose – Ablank) / [ε × path length (cm) × incubation time (min)], where A is adsorption at OD600 and ε is molar absorption coefficient of DCIP (16.3 mM/cm at pH 7.0) (Inose et al., 2003[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]).
Note: In the case of GDHγα, approximately 12 U/mg of specific activity was obtained.
Atomic force microscopy (AFM)
Timing: 4 h
This section describes the binding morphology of surface-immobilized gold binding peptide-fused enzyme could be examined via observing biofilm morphology on a gold substrate.
To remove the dust or organic contaminants on gold coated silicon wafer (e.g., 5 mm × 5 mm), prepare 100 mL of 1:3 (v/v) of 30% H2O2/H2SO4 (piranha solution) in 500 mL beaker.
Incubate the gold substrate in piranha solution for 10 min, at 25°C.
Rinse the gold substrate with deionized water and dry it with pressurized nitrogen gas.
Add 500 μL of 0.1 μM target enzyme dissolved in PBS (pH 7.4) into 1.5 mL microtube.
Insert the surface-cleaned gold substrate in the enzyme solution containing microtube.
Incubate the gold substrate in the enzyme solution-containing microtube, on a rotary shaker of 200 rpm, for 2 h (25°C).
Remove weakly bound proteins on the gold surface by sonication (30 Hz) in enzyme-free PBS for 30 s.
To remove salts on the surface, wash off the surface with stream of deionized water for 30 s.

Dry the protein-bound gold surface with 99.9% nitrogen gas (Sinil Gas, Korea).
Measure the surface morphology of protein-bound gold surface using AFM in non-contact mode.
Fix the protein-bound gold substrate on sample stage of AFM instrument (XE-100; Park Systems, Langen, Germany).
Install the 125-μm Si/Al-coated cantilevers (PPP-NCHR 10 M; Park Systems) with 200–400-kHz resonance frequency and 42 N/m spring constant.
Align the cantilever on the center of sample surface.
Image the surface morphology in 1 μm × 1 μm scan fields, at 1 Hz scan rate.
After Acquiring raw AFM image, process the image flattening to remove the undesired artifacts such as slope and curvature, with XEI software (Park Systems).
Note: In this study, the 1st order fitting curve was utilized during image flattening.
Critical: The enzyme-bound specimen must be fully dried since remained water molecules could cause vertical drift in AFM imaging.
Cyclic voltammetry (CV)
Timing: 2–8 h
This section describes cyclic voltammetry (CV) that is used to measure interfacial electron transfer rate between the enzymatic cofactor and electrode surface. By analyzing the onset potential, the presence of a direct electron transfer signal is identified, and the peak current in the cyclic voltammogram can provide evidence of interfacial direct electron transfer efficiency (Lee et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]).
Note: In the case of FAD-dependent enzyme, it is known that -0.46 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) is ideal onset potential.
Prepare screen-printed gold electrode (SPGE) (DropSens) that consists of Au working electrode (4 mm in diameter), Pt auxiliary electrode, and Ag pseudo-reference electrode (Lee et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]).
Note: Before enzyme immobilization, the SPGE should be verified not to have interfering electrochemical signal by conducting CV with bare SPGE.
Add 800 μL of 0.5 μM target enzyme dissolved in PBS buffer (pH 7.4) into a disposable cuvette.

Immerse the SPGE into the enzyme solution containing cuvette and incubate it on the rotary shaker of 200 rpm, for 2 h at 25°C.
Wash off the excess proteins on the gold working electrode surfaces with a stream of PBS, for 30 s.
Connect the enzyme-modified SPGE to potentiostat (Autolab, Metrohm) via a connector.
Immerse the enzyme-modified SPGE in the reactor (working volume: 10 mL) with 8 mL of 10 mM potassium phosphate buffer (pH 7.4).
Note: To detect glucose-led oxidative current, add 2 M glucose stock dissolved in 10 mM potassium-based phosphate buffer (pH 7.4) for glucose content to be 0–100 mM.
Set the scan rate to be 100 mV/s and perform the CV in the potential range of -500 mV–400 mV, using Nova 1.11 program.
Note: The number of cycles was determined until the signal is stabilized. In this case, the signal was shown to be stabilized after individual 20–30 cycles. Also, when the scan direction is changed to reverse (compared with original direction), we did not observe large difference.
